intro: Draba puvirnituqii, commonly known as the Labrador pitted bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Arctic and subarctic regions of North America. It is a small, herbaceous plant that typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in tundra and alpine environments. The plant produces delicate, clustered flowers that are usually white or pale purple, with five petals and a distinctive pitted center. It is adapted to cold climates and has a short growing season, blooming in late spring to early summer. Draba puvirnituqii plays an important ecological role in its habitat by providing nectar for pollinators and contributing to the biodiversity of high-latitude ecosystems.
